Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: Weaknesses: The food was never enough for all the listeners of the lectures.
I listened to many talks of scholars from different fields, and it really broadened my horizons. However, the arrangement of the topic might be not so friendly for the first year students.

I think the seminar gives us a good way to get to know the up to date research in biostatistics field, but for master student sometimes it is difficult to understand the whole report and we are easily distracted. There are many professors also come to listen, for them it will be much easier.
strength: help me broaden my horizon and learn more about the fields in Biostatistics.

It's during lunch time and it's a requirement for all biostat students, but the food is bad and usually not enough to serve the students...Topics are interesting and good for students to learn from other exports in the biostat filed.
Sometimes the topics are too esoteric
I like learning about the different types of research that the speakers are doing, I find this to be valuable exposure.

I was interested in listening about different presentations as they provide us with knowledge of different fields in biostatistics. However, the presentations are so dense  and technical that no one really knows what the presenters are talking about, and the seminars really end up being a waste of time.

To be frank, this is a waste of time specially for MPH students.  For a good portion of MPH students, this is our semester learning probability and linear methods formally.  And most of the seminars are simply too advanced for us first years MPH students.

What I would recommend is moving this to second year AFTER we've all taken courses in Probability, Theory of Statistics and the core BIS courses in the curriculum.  Has a lot of potential for this course.
I have enjoyed the seminar so far.

It establishes a good environment, but the research topics are most of the time too arcane for students to understand. It feels more like a platform for lecturers/professors to project themselves or practice for their job interview.
A good organizer for the seminar.
He has selected very interesting speakers.
I think this course helps a beginner like me learn about different fields in biostatistics.
maybe more suitable for sophomore students
No. I am not sure whether it is useful for master students, maybe it is more useful for PhD students.
Yes I will recommend. It's a good way to learn from experts.
Would recommend to 2nd years.  Not to 1st years.  Too advanced for 1st years.
Interesting weekly seminar. I would recommend to another student.
